article_title: Chefs from around the country, wine and beer events, BBQ and Halloween dinner
article_text:
MKE Diner News and notes on the restaurant scene from dining critic Carol Deptolla SHARE

By of the

Some big names will be rolling into town for special dinners in the coming weeks, and other events are filling the food and drink calendar this weekend.

Kaysen, Tessier at Bocuse D'Or fundraiser

A celebrated New York-turned-Minneapolis chef, the leading chef on a silver-medal-winning U.S. culinary team and the son of the founder of the Bocuse d'Or are among the chefs who will be at a fundraising dinner Oct. 19 at Lake Park Bistro.

The dinner is a benefit for the U.S. team that will compete in the next Bocuse d'Or, the world culinary championship held every two years in Lyon, France.

Gavin Kaysen, the James Beard Award-winning chef at Cafe Boulud who left New York to open Spoon and Stable in Minneapolis last year, will be at the dinner, as will Phillip Tessier, the culinary director at Heston Vineyards in California and the lead chef on the silver-medal-winning American team at the Bocuse d'Or in January.

Kaysen was the head coach for Team USA this year and he competed in 2007, the same year he was named a Food & Wine magazine best new chef.

Jerome Bocuse, who operates the restaurants in Epcot's France pavilion in Orlando, also will be at the event. His father founded the international culinary competition, and Jerome Bocuse also is the vice president of Ment'Or, the foundation that raises money to fund the American team.

Also scheduled to be at the dinner is Jean-Luc Colombo, the winemaker and owner of Vins Jean-Luc Colombo in France's northern Rhone valley, as well as two more James Beard Award winners: Paul Bartolotta, co-owner of Bartolotta Restaurants and a member of the Ment'Or culinary council, and Adam Siegel, the executive chef of Lake Park Bistro.

The dinner is $150. The restaurant, at 3133 E. Newberry Blvd., is taking reservations at (414) 962-6300.

FT33's McCallister at Ardent

Matt McCallister, the chef-owner of FT33 in Dallas and one of Food & Wine magazine's best new chefs of 2014, will collaborate with chef Justin Carlisle for a dinner at Ardent on Aug. 30.

The multicourse dinner's menu will be finalized the day of the event, to incorporate ingredients in season.

Dinner is $150. To reserve seats, call the restaurant at (414) 897-7022 or email ardentmke@gmail.com.

The date for Ardent's next visiting chefs collaborative dinner also has been set: Sept. 13, featuring Anna Posey (formerly Anna Shovers), a native of MIlwaukee's North Shore who until recently was pastry chef at the Publican in Chicago. She will be opening a restaurant in Chicago next year with her husband, David Posey, who was chef at Blackbird in Chicago.

Patio party at Vanguard

Saturday is the Vanguard's third patio-cookout party, behind the restaurant at 2659 S. Kinnickinnic. This Grill Communication's theme is Latin fare. And a pig roast. With Oskar Blues beers.

It kicks off at noon, and lasts until the food runs out or 6 p.m., whichever comes first. On the menu: ancho-roasted pork with mole, sweet potato and cactus paella, lime chicharones, tortilla and chorizo links.

Wine & Vine Etc.

Saturday also is the date for the 7th annual Wine & Vine Etc. on the grounds of the Sisters of St. Francis of Assisi Convent, 3221 S. Lake Drive, St. Francis.

All of the proceeds go toward restoring the 1912 grape arbor and care of the surrounding green space on the grounds.

Attendees can sample wine, beer, coffee and tea, and try foods from restaurants and other vendors.

It's $50; tickets for attendees younger than 21 or for people who won't be trying wines and beers are $35. Tickets can be bought in advance online or by calling (888) 996-4774. If tickets remain on Saturday, they'll be available at the door as well.

The event runs from 3:30 to 7 p.m. behind the Marion Center for Nonprofits on the grounds.

Bar Bites at Story Hill BKC

Bar Bites, a continuing series at Story Hill BKC that pairs dishes with a featured brewery, returns at 6 p.m. Monday.

Five courses will be paired with beers from O'so Brewing, including Session Sour Series No. 1 and O-toberfest. The $65 cost includes a reception with an appetizer, the beer pairings and tax.

Reservations are needed; make them by calling the restaurant at (414) 539-4424. Story Hill is at 5100 W. Blue Mound Road.

Hinterland's all-you-can-eat barbecue

To celebrate its eighth anniversary, Hinterland at 222 E. Erie St. will have its all-you-can-eat barbecue on Sept. 17.

Ribs, brisket and side dishes, as well as four taps of Hinterland beer, are included in the price of $65.

The barbecue dinner will be available from 6 to 9 p.m. Reserve a seat by calling (414) 727-9300.

Halloween at Odd Duck

This is a party that always sells out quickly: Halloween dinner at Odd Duck.

The restaurant at 2352 S. Kinnickinnic Ave. in Bay View has set its theme: a 16th-century medieval feast in the court of King Henry VIII.

The dinner on Oct. 31 will be seven courses paired with beverages; a vegetarian menu will be available. A reception begins at 6 p.m., and dinner follows at 6:30. It's $90.

Odd Duck encourages costumes but doesn't require them. Reservations, on the other hand, are required, and the restaurant is taking them now. And go: (414) 763-5881.

Pigs and Pinot dinner at Artisan 179

Artisan 179, at 179 W. Wisconsin Ave. in Pewaukee, will have a Pigs and Pinot night on Sept. 22 — five courses paired with various Pinots — as in Noir and Gris — plus a reception with passed appetizers.

Courses include a pancetta goat cheese tart with mushrooms and baby arugula, served with Sokol Blosser's Pinot Noir Rose, and milk-braised pork with celeriac puree and charred heirloom carrot with EnRoute's Pinot Noir.

Dinner is $110 a person; reserve seats by calling the restaurant at (262) 691-0200.

---

Unless noted, prices for dinners and events don't include tax or tip.
